claim: If a safety car had been deployed on lap 15 of the 2011 Australian Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton would have attempted a one-stop strategy.
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim describing a hypothetical scenario ('If a safety car had been deployed... Hamilton would have attempted a one-stop strategy'). The database records what actually happened, not what would have happened under imagined circumstances. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from historical data.

content.text:
This claim is a counterfactual/hypothetical scenario: "If a safety car had been deployed... Lewis Hamilton would have attempted a one-stop strategy." It describes an imagined "what if" situation that never actually happened.

According to my guidelines, counterfactual claims — those describing hypothetical scenarios using language like "If X had happened..." or "Would have..." — cannot be verified from a database that only records what actually happened. They must always be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

There is no need to query the database, as no amount of historical data can tell us what *would have* happened under a hypothetical scenario.

```json
{"label": "NOT ENOUGH INFO", "reasoning": "This is a counterfactual claim describing a hypothetical scenario ('If a safety car had been deployed... Hamilton would have attempted a one-stop strategy'). The database records what actually happened, not what would have happened under imagined circumstances. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from historical data."}
```
